> > Patrik,
> > Agreed the =
wood graining in the saya looks genuine and typical of 
that
> > sort
> > o=
f work I have seen. The brass fittings do not look to be of 
Japanese
> > w=
orkmanship, especially the lack of a proper and neat finish 
where the
> > =
metal
> > edges meet the scabbard wood. This is especially true where the 
=
handle
> > butts
> > up to the habaki. The lack of a facing metal piece to =
the habaki 
indicates
> > poor workmanship. It may all be modern, but the p=
roof of the 
pudding for
> > the
> > blade will be when you take the handle=
 off and see the tang. Do 
this -
> > remove the habaki and take good close=
up photos of both sides of 
the tang
> > and
> > put them up. The blade is =
the typical shape of a Meiji tourist 
piece, but
> > running through the im=
ages again I'm of the opinion that the 
koshirae is
> > modern as it just d=
oes not have the refinement of shape that we 
expect to
> > see in Japanese=
 workmanship. So the blade may be old, but if it 
does not
> > have a clear=
 and distinguishable hamon it is nonetheless a "junk" 
piece.
